def: Raised to lofty height; elevated; extolled; refined; dignified;sublime.Wiser far than Solomon, Of more exalted mind. Milton.Time never fails to bring every exalted reputation to a strictscrutiny. Ames.-- Ex*alt"ed*ly, adv.-- Ex*alt"ed*ness, n. "The exaltedness of some minds." T. Gray.
The part of a harness which passes over the saddle, andsupports the shafts of a cart; -- called also ridgerope, and ridger.Halliwell.
One who, or that which, underprops or supports.
The song or shout of praise, of battle, or of triumph. [R.]
Containing paralogism; illogical. "Paralogical doubt." Sir T.Browne.

Across the direction or course of; as, a fleet standing athwartour course. Athwart hawse, across the stem of another vessel, whetherin contact or at a small distance.-- Athwart ships, across the ship from side to side, or in thatdirection; -- opposed to fore and aft.
A rifle adapted to minie balls.
